Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Parallel Algorithms and Data Structures

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a workshop on the topic of parallel algorithms and data structures to be held at the University of Hawaii at Manoa on December 9-13, 2019. This workshop will bring together researchers in parallel algorithms and from broader algorithms community to present recent advances in modeling modern parallel systems and to perform research solving open problems in parallel algorithms and data structures. Students will be exposed to the research environment and will have an opportunity to engage in research. The University of Hawaii is a Native Hawaiian-serving institution, and the workshop will promote participation by underrepresented groups in computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Summary

The Second Hawaii Workshop on Parallel Algorithms and Data Structures took place on December 9-13, 2019 at the University of Hawaii at Manoa campus. 25 researchers (professors and postdocs) and 15 graduate students attended the workshop.  Funds from NSF were used to support the travel and accommodation of non-local student attendees. There was no registration fee.

2. Objectives

The workshop was organized with three goals in mind:

1. Reignite interest in parallel algorithms research.
2. Bring researchers from wider algorithms community together with researchers in parallel computing.
3. Promote research in provably-efficient algorithms and data structures for modern parallel architectures.

3. Organizational Structure

The organization of the workshop was modeled after the annual Bellairs Winter Workshop on Computational Geometry and the Dagstuhl series of workshops on Data Structures.

On the mornings of the first three days of the workshop consisted of invited talks.  The afternoons and the last two days were reserved for the participants to work on solving open problems, which were proposed by the participants prior to the workshop. At the end of each day, participants presented daily progress of what they have been working on.

4. Outcomes, Dissemination, and Participant Feedback

The workshop started a number of collaborations among the participants. These collaborations led to 6 manuscripts so far,  with one of them already published, two accepted to be published in the coming month, and several collaborations still on-going.

The feedback about the workshop collected from the participants via a survey
was overwhelmingly positive. The average scores to the survey questions on the scale from 0 ("Strongly disagree")  to 4 ("Strongly agree") were:

- The workshop is beneficial for the parallel algorithms community: 3.80
- The workshop helped me grow as a researcher/was beneficial for my own research: 3.92
- I would recommend others to attend: 3.84
- I got interested/started research in new topics, thanks to participation at this workshop: 3.52



Last Modified: 01/09/2021
Modified by: Nodari Sitchinava
